name: @appnest/readme
description: Automatically generate a beautiful best-practice README file based on the contents of your repository
author: Appnest

scripts.b:lib:prebuild: npm run prebuild && npm run b:lib
scripts.git:add:commit:push: git add . && git commit --no-edit --amend --no-verify && git push
scripts.bump:patch: npm version patch && npm run git:add:commit:push
scripts.bump:minor: npm version minor && npm run git:add:commit:push
scripts.bump:major: npm version major && npm run git:add:commit:push
scripts.publish:patch: npm run bump:patch && npm run b:lib:prebuild && npm run publish
scripts.publish:minor: npm run bump:minor && npm run b:lib:prebuild && npm run publish
scripts.publish:major: npm run bump:major && npm run b:lib:prebuild && npm run publish
scripts.push:readme: npm run readme && git add . && git commit -m 'New readme' && git push

readme.text: Use this readme generator to easily generate beautiful readme's like this one! Simply extend your package.json and create a readme blueprint. On Github, the README file is like the landing page of your website because it is the first thing visitors see. You want to make a good first impression.

bullets.Simple: Extremely simple to use - so simple that it almost feels like magic!
bullets.Powerful: Customize almost everything - add your own templates and variables if you like
bullets.Awesome: The tool you don't know you need before you have many different repositories that all need maintenance

templates.name: install
templates.template: Run `npm install [[ readme.ids.npm ]]' to install this library!

table: Whether the element is active or not
